title: Self-Care I Use With Breast Cancer: Hint, It’s More Than a Spa Day!

content: Ever feel like tuning out advice that was not asked for and quite frankly is absurd? Let me tell you, when you are diagnosed with cancer, you get quite a bit of that! Let me just name a few:
Have you tried alkaline water? Drink nothing but that and you’ll be cured!
Have you heard of scorpion venom treatment? You should look into it!
There’s some sort of insect somewhere in the Amazon jungle that can sting you and you’ll be cured, read about it.

You get the picture, right? It happened throughout my entire breast cancer journey. So when I think of self-care, I don’t just think of visiting a spa or receiving a manicure. For me, self-care is taking care of your peace and protecting your body and mental well-being. For that very reason, I had to tune out the unwarranted bits of advice I would receive from people.

During chemotherapy, my body and bones ached tremendously, and when my oncology team let me know that they had an oncology massage therapist on site, I signed up immediately! Unfortunately, at that time they had so many patients sign up that they did not get to me. But they did give me in advance the days that they would be there so that I could let my nurse know as soon as I arrived that I wanted to be placed on the list.

content: They also gave me a website to go to search in my area for other oncology massage therapists, and I was desperate to find some sort of relief. I searched on the site and there was one not too far from where I lived. I contacted her and she let me know that she has special pricing for active treatment patients which I was immensely grateful for.

As someone who had severe side effects from active treatment, I was unable to work. Therefore, my only source of income was disability, and it only paid 60% of my regular earnings, which meant financially I was struggling. However, her special pricing for cancer patients made it affordable for me to go to her at least once a month. It made a world of difference.

content: One other side effect I had during my treatment was nail lifting. I was so afraid to cut my nails and it was also very painful. My mom would take me to a nail salon that specialized in pedicures and manicures for cancer patients in treatment. I was so grateful for the great care and compassion I was shown by the manicurist. This salon took into consideration my lowered immune system and would only allow me and my mom to be in the salon at that time. I was very impressed and also very appreciative.

content: I had several cousins come visit me occasionally and spend time with me. We would watch movies and have great conversations while I had a bit of energy. Spending time with loved ones is also self-care because their company and love make you feel good.
Self-care can come in many forms. The important thing is not to forget to take care of yourself and do something that makes you feel good!
